question: So, what's the deal? If the hospital buys ten new - On the house, huh? Tonic water with lime. Never get me to sell my soul for one of those trips... ... But if you get any more Bulls tickets, Nat, give me a call. Moving through the crowd. Nearly gets hit in the follow-through of an imaginary golf swing. You're slicing, Dave. Don't turn your hip. Hey, Jim.
answer: Richard, I just saw someone who wanted to meet you... Richard Kimble... Alex Lentz. Alex is working on the RDU90 trials for Devlin-Macgregor.

question: Yeah... Three. Livers appeared hepatetic to me. Sure.
answer: Before I forget, I went by the garage this afternoon and picket up the Ferrari. Thanks for the loaner again.

question: They fix it this time?
answer: We'll see. You look fabulous, Helen.

question: Well, I've seen everyone, can we leave?
answer: That would be a little abrupt, don't you think? I'm sorry, I have to get my husband home. You looked handsome tonight...

question: Thank you...
answer: Uh, huh... most men in a tuxedo look like waiters...

question: But me?
answer: You looked more like... a band director. Are we home yet?...

question: Dr. Kimble When? Okay, tell them I'll be there in ten minutes. Tim's got a problem.
answer: Call me on your way home.

question: Cavalry's here.
answer: Patient is a male, forty-three. We pulled his gall bladder and the bleeding started.

question: What's his pro time?
answer: He's at 36 seconds. We got a major bleeder in here.

question: You talk to the family?
answer: None. He's off the street.

question: Okay... I'm clamping. Can he tolerate it? Do we have a choice? Marie, give me a clamp... Your husband know you're here tonight, Marie?... What about this liver?
answer: History's sketchy. Could be an alcoholic.

question: Who referred him?
answer: He's on a drug protocol. RDU90.

question: Hi. I'm five minutes away...
answer: I'm glad it went well. I'll see you in a minute.

question: I'm home. Did you hear who won the Bulls game? Helen?
answer: He's here... still in the house... He's trying to kill me... Richard... He's trying to kill me... my head.

question: Hang on, babe... going to be all right.
answer: My head. Richard my hold me.

question: We've had private investigators interview over a hundred amputees, Richard... ... We can't find this guy.
answer: I know what I saw, Walter.

question: I put you up on the stand to say what you saw without anything that remotely smells like proof and the State's attorney is going to take this one-armed man story and run it up our ass. Look, Richard, you're paying us a lot of money to defend you... A plea to second degree -
answer: I didn't kill my wife.

question: Dr. Nichols. You are aware that Richard Kimble was the only beneficiary of Helen Kimble's estate. 12 million dollars roughly.
answer: I was aware of that. The money meant nothing to him.

question: Yet in your presence, Richard Kimble once said that 'if he had Helen's money he could find plenty of uses.' Did he not?
answer: We were talking about -

question: Yes or no?
answer: On the stand. He finishes his moving description of the events. We see some of the jury has been moved. ... And I was holding her when the officers came in.

question: How tall was this man, Dr. Kimble?
answer: I can't be sure. We were, mostly on the floor, fighting... I couldn't -

question: Did that fight cause the scratches on your face and arms?
answer: No. As I explained -

question: And how did this man enter your house?
answer: I don't know -

question: And you probably don't know why your wife told the emergency operator You were her attacker?
answer: She didn't -

question: Your name is Richard, isn't it? Your gun is a .38, isn't it? Your prints were on the gun, the bullets, the lamp, her neck, weren't they?
answer: Look...

question: Kimble sees
answer: It's locked. Where're your keys?

question: Kimble spots keys. Pitches them to Old Guard. Drags Young Guard to the front for a quick exit. But Old Guard fumbles the key-ring, his hands shaking as much as the bus.
answer: Which one? This? This one?! Help me get him -

question: Good lord...
answer: Point of impact.

question: Biggs, your turn to babysit Newman.
answer: Shit. Come on.

question: You get some rest. Looks like you came a long way for nothing. My men've already done a thorough search from point of impact and found nothing.
answer: Aware of media, proceeds patiently with the young Sheriff. With all due respect, may I suggest check-points starting at a 15-mile radius on I-57, I-24, Route 13 east of -

question: Whoa, whoa, whoa... For what? Prisoners are all dead. The only thing check-points will do is get a lot of good people out here frantic and flood my office with calls.
answer: Well, shit, Sheriff, I'd hate for that to happen... So, I'll be taking over the investigation.

question: On whose authority?
answer: By authority of the Governor of the State of Illinois and the office of the United States Marshal, 5th District Northern Illinois...

question: Okay. You want jurisdiction over this mess, you got it. Shut it down. Wyatt Earp is here to mop up for us.
answer: Please, ladies and gentlemen, step back and give this poor man some room. Always an interesting thing when we find leg irons and no legs in them who held the keys, sir?

question: Please, ladies and gentlemen, step back and give this poor man some room. Always an interesting thing when we find leg irons and no legs in them who held the keys, sir?
answer: Uh, me.

question: Would you be so kind as to show them to me, sir? Second chance.
answer: He mighta got out.

question: His wound bathed in orange antiseptic wash, three stitches already in. With pair of forceps he picks up the needle as he sutures himself. Can you hear me, sir?
answer: 'Scuse me, Doc?... ... Don't know if you heard or not but we're looking for an escaped prisoner from that bus train wreck 'couple hours ago. Thought he might show up here if he was hurt.

question: What's he look like?
answer: Approximately six one, 180 pounds, brown hair, brown eyes and beard. ... Seen anyone that fits that description?

question: Every time I look in the mirror ... but without the beard. Excuse me...
answer: Sure.

question: Hit me.
answer: Richard David Kimble. Vascular Surgeon. Convicted of first-degree murder in the killing of his wife. Pleaded innocent. Claimed a one-armed -

question: Let's not retry the case. Priors and accomplices?
answer: None. No previous arrests.

question: Running outta map, Sam.
answer: Just the way we want it. Okay, people, let's button up. Seal it up.

question: Got him.
answer: Okay, ladies and gentlemen hard part's over.

question: Hell, no. You're with me, Newman. Let's go. U.S. Marshals. Down! Down! Motions Newman to the left to check the door off the living room while he moves down the main hall into the back bedroom.
answer: Surges out, knocks Newman's gun from his hand. In a flash, Copeland yanks Newman's arm behind his back and presses a knife against the deputy's neck and moves him out of the room.

question: He hears Copeland moving somewhere in the front of the house.
answer: I got your man! Now I want outta here! You hear me? I said, I want out or I'll cut your man's throat!

question: Keeps moving down the hallway, through first bedroom, pauses at door to the second bedroom and chooses his course. Shut up.
answer: My ear... I can't hear a thing out of it. I can't believe you did that!

question: You think I should have bargained with him, don't you?
answer: Yes. You could've missed! You could've killed me!

question: Yeah, you're absolutely right. I could've. How bad's your ear?
answer: Terrible. I probably have permanent hearing damage.

question: Walter. It's Richard.
answer: Richard... Jesus, why did you run? Running only makes you look guilty.

question: I wasn't worrying about appearances, Walter.
answer: Tell me where you are. I'll come meet you so you can turn yourself in .

question: I'm not turning myself in. I need money.
answer: Richard. You're asking me to harbor and aid a convicted felon... I can't help you that way. My advice - both as a friend and as your legal counsel - is for you to give yourself up. Now tell me... where are you?

question: St. Louis.
answer: Give me an address. I'll be -

question: Creature of habit, Sharon. Not today, please. No. Not - Oh, my God... Richard...
answer: How're you doing, Charlie?

question: You're alive...
answer: Yeah. And I need your help.

question: Anything.
answer: I need some money. Whatever you've got on you.

question: Of course. Tell me where you're staying. I'll get you more money. Some clothes. Just give me an address...
answer: I'll call you.

question: I know why you came back - to find him. If I can help, call me... Call me.
answer: Thanks, Charlie...

question: Richard Kimble... I saw him two days ago. He stopped me in my car. I gave him some money.
answer: Where was this?

question: Outside our tennis - - my tennis club.
answer: Did he ask you for help?

question: I volunteered. He wouldn't accept it.
answer: Why do you think he came back to Chicago?

question: He didn't tell me.
answer: I didn't ask you that, sir. I'm sure he was trying to protect you from having to lie for him. If you're really his friend, you'll help us bring him in unharmed.

question: Why, so he can go back to prison? If you want help, gentlemen, you've come to the wrong man.
answer: Dr. Nichols, last year the U.S. Marshals' office closed out 11,003 warrants... 10,975 of those were captured. The twenty-eight others thought they were smarter than us... Now they're dead. Nice car. Stay on him.

question: Hey, how're you doing?
answer: Fine.

question: You find that sign?
answer: Yes, I did.

question: You called me an asshole.
answer: Excuse me. I was having a bad shift.

question: You worked at other hospitals?
answer: Lots of them over the years. Here, long ago. Hasn't changed much.

question: Do you have a particular interest in our patients' x-rays?
answer: What do you mean?

question: I saw you looking at that boy's chest film.
answer: It's a hobby of mine -

question: What other hobbies do you have? Brain surgery?
answer: What do you want?

question: I want to know how that kid ended up in surgery.
answer: I'm a janitor. I did what I was told.

question: Bullshit. Who changed those orders? You stand right here. I'm calling security.
answer: A man posing as a janitor orders an emergency operation and all you do is pull his I.D.?

question: A little boy's alive today because he did something.
answer: So, you weren't aware that when he escaped he was being transported to Menard State Prison to begin a term of life imprisonment.

question: For what?
answer: For murdering his wife. Thank you for your help, Doctor.

question: Then you wait. Climbing the stairs. He reaches a landing - and skims shoulders with Kimble, who pivots past on his way down. Kimble. Kimble!
answer: Officers - there's a man in the stairwell waving a gun and screaming.

question: U.S. Marshal! Get on the phone, call your commander, tell him there's a top-fifteen warrant in the building. Go. Bursts out the stairwell door after Kimble. Kimble. Stop!
answer: Enters the revolving doors as a big man enters from the outside. The big man sizes up the situation, realizes Kimble is fleeing and just before Kimble exits - yanks on the door - trapping him partially inside the revolving door.

question: Looks up. He's found the man he's looking for but also a new possibility - that the murder wasn't just a random act of violence.
answer: Renfro, Biggs... This is Gerard.

question: Do you remember what I told you in the tunnel?
answer: You told me, you didn't kill your wife.

question: Remember what you said to me?
answer: I remember you were pointing my gun at me.

question: You said, 'I don't care.'
answer: That's right, Kimble... I'm not trying to solve a puzzle here. I'm just the poor working man that's paid to hunt you down.

question: What the hell's going on here? Who are you people?
answer: You had a break-in, Mr. Sykes.

question: You a cop?
answer: My name is Gerard. U.S. Marshal's Office. This morning a fugitive named Richard Kimble made a call from your apartment.

question: Richard Kimble... I don't know a Richard Kim - Wait a minute... This is the doctor who killed his wife... He claimed the killer had a prosthetic limb. You telling me he's coming after me?
answer: Would he have a reason to?

question: What the hell's that supposed to mean? Because I have this? Look, a year ago some people came to see me. They asked me questions about the night of the murder and I'll tell you the same thing I told them. I wasn't even in town then. I was on a business trip.
answer: What kind of business are you in, Mr. Sykes?

question: Security.
answer: Independent?

question: No, I work for a pharmaceutical company. I handle security for its top executives.
answer: Any idea why Kimble would be interested in these?

question: No. Just some doctors on a company junket. Look, you mind if I talk to the cops to see if anything's missing?
answer: By all means.

question: It's very important I reach him. Can you talk?
answer: Richard. Yes... I'm on a hotel phone. What's going on?

question: I found him, Charlie. I found the guy that killed Helen.
answer: What?

question: It's all about a drug, Charlie. They tried to kill me because of a drug.
answer: Who?

question: Devlin-MacGregor and Lentz. Lentz was supervising the R.D.U.90 protocol. He knew I'd found out the drug had problems. It's Lentz.
answer: Richard, Lentz is dead. He died in an auto accident last summer. Can you prove this about the drug?

question: I don't know him. You're getting pretty desperate aren't you, Mr. Gerard. I told you, you wouldn't find Richard.
answer: Dr. Kimble hasn't come back to you for help, has he?

question: No. And it seems like we've been over this ground before. Now if you'll excuse me.
answer: Dr. Nichols. Do you know the other man in the photograph?

question: Half the people in the study were indigents. No follow-up, no baseline on them. Who could say they didn't come into the study with bad livers?
answer: The one on the right is one of the samples you sent me. It shows a lot of perriportal inflammation loaded with eosinophils. When you see that with the accumulation of bile it's a classic for -

question: - drug induced hepatitis.
answer: I'm impressed. Now look at this. According to the study, this is a slice from the same liver.

question: Cold normal.
answer: Clearly not from the same tissue. In fact. See this small area of bile duct proliferation? Von Meyenberg's Complex. Occurs in only 2% of the population. But it's in every one of your five samples.

question: That's statistically impossible.
answer: That's because they're all from the same liver.

question: He's dead.
answer: Yeah, we heard. We wanted to know if he knew or had any contact with Dr. Richard Kimble?

question: I... I haven't seen Dr. Kimble.
answer: That's not what I asked, sir. I just wanted to know if Dr. Kimble and Dr. Lentz knew each other?

question: They'd be home free if I hadn't been leaning on them to account for the livers I was seeing. And I wouldn't have seen the livers if I hadn't told the guys on my service to call me when they had cases that were bleeding excessively in surgery.
answer: Big bucks. One schmuck standing in the way. Easy, get rid of him and his wife. But why Lentz?

question: Why not? He's one of the original patent holders. Toss the samples I sent, replace them with healthy samples, issue the path report on the healthy stuff-piece of cake. When did Lentz die?
answer: Oh, last summer sometime. August... Why?

question: Because a good third of the samples Lentz approved were signed after he died. Someone else used Lentz's name.
answer: A pathologist at Devlin-Macgregor?

question: They wouldn't have had the access. They would have needed someone at the hospital.
answer: Where are you going?

question: Get CPD to bring in Sykes.
answer: I checked Sykes' calls for the last two years against Kimble's like you asked and found nothing.

question: All right. It was a thought.
answer: But when I cross-checked Kimble's phone records... one came up.

question: Kimble called Sykes. Renfro! Get C.P.D. to bring in Sykes!
answer: Night of his wife's murder - seven-thirty in the evening from his car. I have the phone record right here.

question: ... And I especially would like to thank my researchers who helped me... Richard...
answer: What's wrong, Charlie? Surprised? After Lentz died, you were the only one that had access to the pathology reports.

question: Reports? What are you?
answer: You switched the samples and falsified the reports so R.D.U.90 could get approval.

question: Richard, I don't know what you're talking about?...
answer: I have a set of the original samples. You almost pulled it off, Charlie. But I know all about it now, and I can prove it. Ladies and gentlemen. My friend, as you can see, is obviously not well. Richard, if you want to talk - I didn't come here to talk
